title: Spack not using compiler from packages section of spack.yaml
body:
I am using a `spack.yaml` file to create an environment inside a Docker container. In order to keep configuration simple and to a minimum I am putting all of it into `spack.yaml`. In particular, I would like to use a particular version of `gcc` to build all of my specs (8.4.0). Here's an example of what my `spack.yaml` looks like:

```yaml
spack:
    specs:
        - python@3.7.8
        - py-pip
    concretization: together
    view: true
    packages:
        all:
            compiler:: [gcc@8.4.0]
        gcc:
            version: [8.4.0]
            buildable: true
    config:
        install_missing_compilers: true
```

### Steps to reproduce the issue

To build the Docker image, I copy the `spack.yaml` file to `/etc/spack.yaml` in the container, clone a fresh copy of `spack`, and create an environment. E.g.:

```dockerfile
COPY spack.yaml /etc/
RUN git clone $SPACK_URL $SPACK_ROOT && \
. $SPACK_ROOT/share/spack/setup-env.sh && \
spack env create myenv /etc/spack.yaml && \
spack activate myenv && \
spack install
```
My expectation is that `spack` will use `gcc@8.4.0` to build Python and will build `gcc@8.4.0` in the process. However, `spack` uses the system `gcc` instead (4.8.5).

Importantly, in keeping with the double colon after `compiler` in the `all` section of `packages`, after the environment is activated if I run `spack config get packages` it shows `gcc@8.4.0` as the only suggested compiler:

```console
$ spack config get packages
packages:
  all:
    compiler: [gcc@8.4.0]
    providers:
      D: [ldc]
      awk: [gawk]
      blas: [openblas]
      daal: [intel-daal]
      elf: [elfutils]
      fftw-api: [fftw]
      gl: [mesa+opengl, opengl]
      glx: [mesa+glx, opengl]
      glu: [mesa-glu, openglu]
      golang: [gcc]
      iconv: [libiconv]
      ipp: [intel-ipp]
      java: [openjdk, jdk, ibm-java]
      jpeg: [libjpeg-turbo, libjpeg]
      lapack: [openblas]
      mariadb-client: [mariadb-c-client, mariadb]
      mkl: [intel-mkl]
      mpe: [mpe2]
      mpi: [openmpi, mpich]
      mysql-client: [mysql, mariadb-c-client]
      opencl: [pocl]
      pil: [py-pillow]
      pkgconfig: [pkgconf, pkg-config]
      rpc: [libtirpc]
      scalapack: [netlib-scalapack]
      sycl: [hipsycl]
      szip: [libszip, libaec]
      tbb: [intel-tbb]
      unwind: [libunwind]
    permissions:
      read: world
      write: user
    buildable: true
    version: []
    target: []
  gcc:
    version: [8.4.0]
    buildable: true
    target: []
    providers: {}
    compiler: []
```

Whereas if you just make it a single colon it merely prepends `gcc@8.4.0` to the list of suggested compilers:

```console
$ spack config get packages
packages:
  all:
    compiler: [gcc@8.4.0, gcc, intel, pgi, clang, xl, nag, fj]
    providers:
      D: [ldc]
      awk: [gawk]
      blas: [openblas]
      daal: [intel-daal]
      elf: [elfutils]
      fftw-api: [fftw]
      gl: [mesa+opengl, opengl]
      glx: [mesa+glx, opengl]
      glu: [mesa-glu, openglu]
      golang: [gcc]
      iconv: [libiconv]
      ipp: [intel-ipp]
      java: [openjdk, jdk, ibm-java]
      jpeg: [libjpeg-turbo, libjpeg]
      lapack: [openblas]
      mariadb-client: [mariadb-c-client, mariadb]
      mkl: [intel-mkl]
      mpe: [mpe2]
      mpi: [openmpi, mpich]
      mysql-client: [mysql, mariadb-c-client]
      opencl: [pocl]
      pil: [py-pillow]
      pkgconfig: [pkgconf, pkg-config]
      rpc: [libtirpc]
      scalapack: [netlib-scalapack]
      sycl: [hipsycl]
      szip: [libszip, libaec]
      tbb: [intel-tbb]
      unwind: [libunwind]
    permissions:
      read: world
      write: user
    buildable: true
    version: []
    target: []
  gcc:
    version: [8.4.0]
    buildable: true
    target: []
    providers: {}
    compiler: []
```

Since I have pinned `gcc` to version 8.4.0, in the above case you would doubly expect `spack` to use `gcc@8.4.0` regardless.

If I directly specify in the Python spec that I want to compile with `gcc@8.4.0`, then `spack` does build `gcc@8.4.0` before building Python with it. I.e. this works:

```yaml
spack:
    specs:
        - python@3.7.8 %gcc@8.4.0
        - py-pip
    concretization: together
    view: true
    config:
        install_missing_compilers: true
```

It seems that the `packages` section is not used for compiler selection during concretization if the compiler is not already present even with `install_missing_compilers: true`.

### Information on your system

```bash
$ spack debug report
* **Spack:** 0.14.1-2401-06b64c3
* **Python:** 2.7.5
* **Platform:** linux-centos7-haswell
```

### Additional information

- [x] I have run `spack debug report` and reported the version of Spack/Python/Platform
- [x] I have searched the issues of this repo and believe this is not a duplicate
- [ ] I have run the failing commands in debug mode and reported the output
